Fig. 1 Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of: (a) Ni/La-Al2O3, (b) Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3, (c) Ni/La-TiO2, (d) Ni/La-Clay. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of fresh catalysts: (a) Ni/La-Al2O3, (b) Ni/La-TiO2, (c) Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3, (d) Ni/La-Clay. Symbols: Y, γ-Al2O3; A, anatase; R, rutile; M, montmorillonite; Q, quartz. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Ethanol conversion in ESR at 500 °C as function of reaction time over fresh (A) and reactivated catalysts (B). Symbols: olive squares, Ni/La-Al2O3; red triangles, Ni/La/TiO2-Al2O3; black circles, Ni/La-TiO2; blue diamonds, Ni/La-Clay (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Hydrogen yield in ESR at 500 °C as function of reaction time over fresh (A) and reactivated catalysts (B). Symbols as in Fig. 3. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 ESR at 500 °C on Ni/La-TiO2. Product yields as function of reaction time: (a) fresh and (b) reactivated catalyst. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 ESR at 500 °C on Ni/La-Clay. Product yields as function of reaction time: (a) fresh and (b) reactivated catalyst. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 ESR at 500 °C on Ni/La-Al2O3. Product yields as function of reaction time: (a) fresh and (b) reactivated catalyst. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 ESR at 500 °C Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3. Graphical abstract The effect of support nature on the catalytic performance of Ni-based catalysts for ethanol steam reforming (ESR) was investigated. Nickel catalysts supported on lanthanum-modified Al2O3, TiO2, Al2O3-TiO2 and Al-pillared bentonite (denoted as Clay) were prepared by impregnation, characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsoption-desorption, IR spectroscopy of acetonitrile adsorption and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and evaluated at 500 °C under atmospheric pressure. Both Ni/La-Al2O3 and Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3 exhibited the best stability, whereas Ni/La-TiO2 and Ni/La-Clay deactivated quickly but with similar or higher H2 production. Catalyst deactivation was caused by carbon deposition, which formation was related to strong Brønsted sites. Efficiency of lanthanum as inhibitor of carbon deposition depended on the support nature. Oxidative regeneration allowed recovering initial activity of all used catalysts and even improving the performance of the latter two catalysts. This unexpected improvement can be due to change of nickel centres nature, caused by local overheating during the deposited carbon combustion. Keywords Ethanol steam reforming Nickel catalysts Effect of support nature Lanthanum as modifier Acid properties Catalyst deactivation and regeneration 1 Introduction The increasing awareness of the impact of greenhouse gases in the climate change has boosted the research carried out in order to replace fossil fuels by clean fuels from renewable resources. Hydrogen can be considered as an alternative, clean and environmentally ideal fuel [1–3]. Hydrogen can be obtained by a range of catalytic processes from many different resources, but reducing the emission of greenhouse gases requires renewable resources and notably those from biomass. In this context, the use of ethanol as resource remains among the most widely used methods because ethanol is less toxic, less volatile, easily transportable and more abundant than other compounds produced from biomass [4,5]. Among the various chemical applications to produce hydrogen from it, steam reforming of ethanol (ESR) is being extensively studied because it gives the highest amount of hydrogen per mol of ethanol (6 mol per mol) [6,7]: (1) C 2 H 5 O H + 3 H 2 O → 6 H 2 + 2 C O 2 Δ H 298 ° = 174 k J · m o l − 1 As it is highly endothermic, it requires quite high temperature conditions (Eq.1) [8,9]. However, depending on the materials and conditions used, the ESR can be partial and accompanied by several side reactions and, therefore, by several by-products [10,11]. The main possible reactions are described below [8,12]: Partial reforming (2) C H 3 C H 2 O H + H 2 O → 2 C O + 4 H 2 Δ H 298 ° = 256 k J · m o l − 1 Dehydrogenation (3) C H 3 C H 2 O H → C H 3 C H O + H 2 Δ H 298 ° = 68 k J · m o l − 1 Dehydration (4) C H 3 C H 2 O H → C 2 H 4 + H 2 O Δ H 298 ° = 68 k J · m o l − 1 Carbon formation (5) n C 2 H 4 → [ p o l y m e r s ] → C Δ H 298 ° = − 171 k J · m o l − 1 Acetaldehyde steam reforming (6) C H 3 C H O + 3 H 2 O → 2 C O 2 + 5 H 2 Δ H 298 ° = 105 k J · m o l − 1 Acetaldehyde partial reforming (7) C H 3 C H O + H 2 O → 2 C O + 3 H 2 Δ H 298 ° = 187 k J · m o l − 1 Acetaldehyde decomposition (8) C H 3 C H O → C H 4 + C O Δ H 298 ° = − 19 k J · m o l − 1 Acetaldehyde condensation (9) 2 C H 3 C H O → C H 3 C O C H 3 + C O + H 2 Δ H 298 ° = 5 k J · m o l − 1 Water gas shift (WGS) (10) C O + H 2 O → H 2 + C O 2 Δ H 298 ° = − 41 k J · m o l − 1 CO2 methanation (11) C O 2 + 4 H 2 → C H 4 + 2 H 2 O Δ H 298 ° = − 165 k J · m o l − 1 The presence of the C–C bond and CO in the reaction products are two major hurdles related to ESR [1]. Therefore, to develop more appropriate catalytic materials, it is necessary to better understand the reaction pathways and the role of catalyst in each step involved [3,13]. The activity of the catalyst in this type of reaction depends on several parameters such as the nature of the support and the metal, the promoters, the precursors and preparation method used, as well as on the reaction conditions, notably, water/ethanol molar ratio and temperature [14]. Many materials have been investigated to develop effective catalysts for the ESR, such as oxides, oxides supported transition or noble metals, which have shown sufficient activity and stability to be used [15,16]. Among the transition metals studied Ni gives good activity. Ni-based catalysts are very competitive compared to noble metal-based catalysts despite the low cost of Ni [16]. Researchers have classified the metals used according to their activity as follows: Rh > Pd > Ni = Pt [17]. Nickel has been shown to be an active metal that breaks C–C and C–H bonds; therefore, Ni-based catalysts are promising materials for ESR reaction [5,18–20]. Due to their activity and low cost, Ni-based catalysts are widely used in other various fields and applications, including industrial petrochemical applications such as hydrogenation and dehydrogenation [13,21,22]. The nature of the support has a significant effect on catalyst activity, selectivity and resistance to deactivation [23]. It has been shown that the choice of support influences the nature of the carbonaceous products formed along with the reaction. Thus, due to the sintering of metallic nickel and/or the formation of coke, it is necessary to develop supports that ensure the stability of nickel-based catalysts [18]. Many oxides and mixed oxides are widely used as supports in ESR. Among them, aluminium oxide remains the most used in the reforming reaction because of its chemical and mechanical resistance. Nevertheless, when used alone, this oxide promotes the formation of C2H4 which is a coke precursor. To avoid deactivation, this oxide is often modified by the addition of other oxides [16,24–26]. A study of different Ni/Al2O3, Ni/Y2O3 and Ni/La2O3 catalysts showed that the two latter catalysts have high activity and hydrogen selectivity [13]. Titanium oxide has been also used as a support for Ni catalyst, but Ni/TiO2 causes strong coking [27] and, due to the similar ionic radii of Ti4+ and Ni2+, when calcined at high temperatures nickel atoms can be incorporated to the TiO2 phase, which reduces the number of active sites [28]. Nevertheless, it has been reported that the incorporation of TiO2 to alumina leads to the stabilization of the catalyst in the ESR by weakening the strength of the acid sites [29]. Cerium oxide is widely used as a support because of its high oxygen storage capacity, and high oxygen mobility. It has been shown that this oxide modifies the electronic properties of nickel, helps to break O–H bonds and prevents carbon deposits [30,31]. The major disadvantage of nickel-based catalysts is their deactivation by carbon deposition [32]. To solve this problem, the catalysts’ improvement is achieved by modifying supports with the addition of alkali metals, rare earth oxides and other basic oxides, which decrease acidity, increase oxygen mobility, improve metal dispersion and prevent sintering of metal sites [33–38]. For instance, doping of zeolite Y with alkali increases the H2 yield in the order: Ni/Na-Y < Ni/K-Y < Ni/Cs-Y [39]. The modification of ZrO2 with Y2O3 and CaO decreases the CO formation, thus increasing the H2 selectivity [40]. Addition of rare earths to Ni/Al2O3 catalysts improves both selectivity and catalyst stability due to the reduced Lewis acidity of the Al2O3 support and the facility to remove carbon deposits [41]. Among the modifiers used, those of lanthanide-group have been employed in a large number of reactions [32,42]; the presence of lanthanides produces an important dispersing effect and strengthens CO2 adsorption on the support [43]. Aluminium oxide modified with lanthanum exhibits greater stability [19,44] in the methane dry reforming reaction than Al2O3 alone [43,45]. Lanthanum also improves catalyst reducibility and catalytic performance in the dry reforming of ethanol [46]. Among a wide range of rare earth elements (Sc, Y, La, Er and Gd) modifiers, lanthanum was the most efficient in reducing the formation of coke precursors during the ESR on Rh/Al2O3 catalysts [16]. However, to our knowledge, lanthanum-modified supports have not been investigated for ESR on nickel catalysts. On the other hand, the use of raw materials of lower cost, locally available and easy to transform can contribute to the sustainability of the ESR process. Clays have also shown their performance as supports for nickel in ESR by giving good H2 selectivity due to the broad dispersion of NiO and an improved coke resistance [20,21]. For example, Ni catalyst supported on TiO2-modified-clay gives ethanol conversion around 89 % with 55 % hydrogen as the main product at 500 °C [20]. The aim of this work was study to the effect of lanthanum-modified supports nature on the activity, stability and regenerability of nickel catalysts for hydrogen production by ESR. Besides commercial alumina and titania, and looking for the applicability of easily available natural materials, an Algerian bentonite from Mostaganem (West of Algeria) was explored as a support for the first time. Nickel-based catalysts were prepared by impregnation of the lanthanum-doped supports, and characterized by several analytic methods such as XRD, TGA, BET and FTIR. It has been found that the stabilizing effect of lanthanum depends on the nature of the support. Interestingly, and despite its low catalytic stability, the catalyst supported on the modified clay showed the highest initial activity, and the highest hydrogen production after oxidative regeneration; this could be a promising starting point for the research of naturally available materials as supports for this type of catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals The following chemicals were used for the preparation of catalysts: TiO2 (Sigma-Aldrich, ≥99.5 %), La(NO3)3.6H2O (Sigma-Aldrich, ≥99 %), γ-Al2O3 (Alfa Aesar, >99 %), Ni(NO3)2.6H2O (Sigma-Aldrich, ≥97 %), Al(NO3)3.9H2O (Sigma-Aldrich, ≥98 %), NaCl (Sigma-Aldrich, ≥99 %), and bentonite (with 45–60 % montmorillonite) from Mostaganem (West of Algeria), with chemical composition (wt%): SiO2 (65.2), Al2O3 (17.2), Fe2O3 (2.1), MgO (3.1), CaO (1.2), Na2O3 (2.1), K2O (0.6) and TiO2 (0.2). Ethanol absolute (Pharmpur) was used for catalytic tests. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis TiO2-Al2O3 (10 wt.% TiO2) mixed oxide was prepared by mechanical mixture of finely ground commercial γ-Al2O3 and TiO2. Alumina was hydrolysed in excess water at 80 °C for 16 h under mechanical stirring, then titanium oxide was added; after 5 h of stirring, the mixture was dried at 120 °C for 24 h and calcined in air for 3 h at 400 °C. The bentonite was pillared according to the procedure of Pizarro et al. [47]. Shortly, aluminium pillaring solution (20 mmol Al/g clay, OH/Al = 2 molar ratio) was added dropwise (3 mL.min−1) with stirring to Na-exchanged bentonite suspension (1 wt%), and the solid was calcined at 350 °C in air for 2 h. The resulting pillared bentonite will be denoted hereinafter as Clay. All the supports were modified by wet impregnation with lanthanum nitrate (10 wt.% La/support). The slurry obtained after impregnation was dried at 120 °C overnight and subsequently calcined in air at 350 °C for 2 h. Catalysts (10 wt.% Ni) were prepared in similar way by wet impregnation of the modified supports, and calcined at 350 °C in air for 2 h. The catalysts will be denoted hereinafter as Ni/La-Al2O3, Ni/La-TiO2, Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3 and Ni/La-Clay. 2.3 Characterization The textural properties of the samples were analyzed by N2 adsorption at 77 K (−196 °C) using a Micromeritics ASAP 2420 instrument. Specific surface areas were determined by the BET method. Total pore volume was calculated from the amount of N2 adsorbed at 0.975 relative pressure. Micropore volume was assessed by the t-plot method using the Harkins and Jura model. Pore size distribution was determined using the BJH method applied to the adsorption branch. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded using a PANalytical X'Pert Pro diffractometer, with Cu Kα (λ =0.15419 nm) radiation source. The sample was scanned within the scan range of 2θ = 4° to 90°, under the following conditions: dwell time: 20 s; step 2.3° 2θ; soller slit: 0.04. Thermogravimetric (TGA) curves were obtained using a TGA7 analyser (PerkinElmer instruments). The temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) measurement was made under atmospheric air from room temperature (RT) up to 800 °C with a heating rate of 20 °C.min−1. The surface acidity of the catalysts was investigated by means of the Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopic study of adsorbed acetonitrile. FTIR spectra were recorded with a Thermo Nicolet Nexus 670 FTIR Spectrophotometer, equipped with a MCT detector. The experiments were performed in situ using a purpose-made glass IR cell provided with CaF2 windows, connected to a conventional vacuum-adsorption apparatus. Samples were prepared as self-supporting wafers (thickness ca. 10 mg/cm2) and treated under vacuum at 350 °C for 2 h. The pre-treated sample wafers were cooled down to RT, kept in contact with a 14 mbar pulse of CD3CN (Aldrich, 99.8 % at. D) for 15 min and finally the IR cell was evacuated for 10 min at RT. The spectra of adsorbed acetonitrile were deconvoluted into Gaussian components using Microcal Origin v8.5 software. 2.4 Catalytic experiments The catalytic tests for ethanol (EtOH) reforming were performed using 100 mg of catalyst sample diluted in SiC (catalyst/SiC = 1/3 v/v) in a fixed bed down-flow reactor installed inside the equipment Microactivity Reference model MAXXXM3 (PID Eng& Tech). Reaction temperature was measured with a coaxial thermocouple inserted in the catalytic bed. Catalyst activation was carried out with a flow of 100 mL/min of 10 % O2 in He using a heating ramp of 10 °C/min up to 650 °C and keeping this temperature for 1 h. After activation, the catalyst sample was flushed with He for 10 min. Then the feed mixture (EtOH:H2O = 1:6 molar) was pumped to the evaporator operating at 165 °C. The reaction was carried out for 6 h under atmospheric pressure and 500 °C with feed of molar composition water:ethanol:He = 18.4:3.1:78.5. After the first run, catalyst reactivation treatment was performed at the same conditions of the initial activation, prior to conduct a second run of the reaction. Reactants and reaction products were analysed on line with a Varian chromatograph Model Star 3400 CX equipped with TCD. Catalytic activity was calculated in terms of ethanol conversion (X), and yield (Y i) and selectivity (Si) of products, expressed in mol%. Yields of carbon-containing compounds (i) were calculated by (12) Y i = F i C i 2 F E t O H - i n . 100 where Ci is the number of carbon atoms in compound i, and Fi is its molar flow (mol/h), and FEtOH in represents molar flow of ethanol in the feed. Ethanol conversion was calculated as the sum of the yields of carbon containing products, (13) X E t O H = ∑ Y i (14) S i = Y i X E t O H . 100 Taking into account the stoichiometry of ESR reaction (1), yield and selectivity of hydrogen were calculated as: (15) Y H 2 = F H 2 o u t 6 F E t O H i n . 100 (16) S H 2 = Y H 2 o u t 6 ( F E t O H i n - F E t O H o u t ) . 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization Fig. 1 shows the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the catalysts. All but that of Ni/La-TiO2 showed IUPAC type IV adsorption isotherms, typical of mesoporous materials (pores in the 2−50 nm range), but with different hysteresis profiles. Those of Ni/La-Al2O3 and Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3 (Fig. 1(a) and (b)) are type H1, usually related to agglomerates of homogeneous particles, whereas the isotherm of sample Ni/La-Al-Clay (Fig. 1(d)) shows a type H3 loop, characteristic of agglomerated plate-like particles, typical for pillared clays. The isotherm of Ni/La-TiO2 (Fig. 1(c)) is IUPAC type V, characteristic of very weak adsorption interaction, with a narrow hysteresis at p/p0 > 0.9, related to macropores (>50 nm) formed among particles (interparticular). Pore size distributions (Fig. S1, Supplementary Information) of Ni/La-Al2O3 and Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3 were quite similar, unimodal and broad (5−50 nm) with maxima around 12 nm, and that of Ni/La-TiO2 was also similar but shifted to bigger pore diameters (20−100 nm, maximum at 60 nm). The isotherm of Ni/La-Clay (Fig. 1(d)) indicates a broad pore size distribution of mesopores (probably interparticular). The forced closure of the desorption branch near 0.4 relative pressure, due to the tensile strength effect (TSE) [48], implies that part of the adsorbed nitrogen evaporates through openings that are smaller than the TSE limit value of ca. 3.8 nm, indicating that the interlaminar spaces of clay are smaller than this value (i.e., the pillars are shorter than 3.8 nm). The four catalysts are virtually free of micropores as shown from t-plot analysis, which indicates a micropore volume of less than 0.01 cm3/g in all cases. The BET surface areas (SBET), pore volumes (VPORE) of the catalysts and their corresponding unmodified and La-modified supports are given in Table 1 . In the four systems, addition of lanthanum as a promoter and Ni impregnation decreased the specific surface area, which means a change in the textural properties of the samples [49]. This observation points towards the blocking of some small pores by La2O3. The decrease is more significant in the case of Clay, probably due to its microporous texture. Interestingly, the properties of Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3 system and its evolution are quite similar to those of the system Ni/La-Al2O3 and quite different of those of Ni/La-TiO2. This points to the fact that, due to the synthesis method, the titania particles remain in the core of the mixed support particles and the external surface is practically similar to that of single alumina. The low SBET of titania-based materials is related to the absence of micropores, and its decrease with La modification, together with the increase of its DPORE, seems to indicate that La is acting as a binder of the titania particles and stabilizing the surface area, that remained unchanged by the further Ni deposition. The loss of SBET of pillared clay by impregnation with La is the biggest observed, which must be related to its microporous structure. However, as with La-TiO2, lanthanum stabilizes SBET during Ni deposition. The XRD patterns of the samples (Fig. 2 ) show peaks corresponding to γ-Al2O3 and mixture of anatase and rutile phases for Ni/La-Al2O3 and Ni/La-TiO2, respectively. In the other hand, diffractogram of Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3 (Fig. 2c) shows only the peaks of both γ-Al2O3 and TiO2 phases; this means that probably there is no interaction between the two oxides. Peaks corresponding to nickel containing phases were not detected in the XRD pattern of any sample, probably due to their high dispersion. Moreover, no lanthana characteristic peaks were detected, indicating lanthanum species were either amorphous or well dispersed [50]. The XRD patterns of used catalysts (Fig. S2, Supplementary Information), showed no changes compared to those of fresh catalysts. The adsorption of probe molecules followed by FTIR is often used to characterize acidic and basic sites. Acetonitrile was selected to evaluate catalysts acidity as this probe molecule has extensively been used to characterise different oxides owing to its small size, weak basicity and its ability to differentiate Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [51,52]. Upon adsorption of acetonitrile on the catalysts, bands developed in the 2350−2200 cm−1 region of the FTIR spectra, which correspond to the stretching of the CN group of CD3CN interacting with Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. Adsorption of acetonitrile on acid sites produces a shift of the CN stretching band to higher frequency respect to liquid CD3CN. The magnitude of this shift increases with the strength of the acid sites, in the range 30−60 cm−1 for acetonitrile adsorbed on Lewis sites, and in the range 10−30 cm−1 for acetonitrile adsorbed on Brønsted sites [51]. The spectra (Fig. S3, Supplementary Information) show asymmetric bands corresponding to CD3CN adsorbed on both Lewis (ca. 2310 cm−1) and Brønsted sites (ca. 2270 cm−1). For quantitative analysis, both bands have been fitted by 1 or 2 overlapping Gaussian curves. The concentration of acid sites titrated by acetonitrile has been estimated from the integrated absorbance of the composite bands at ca. 2310 and 2270 cm−1. The extinction coefficients were taken as those determined by Wichterlová et al. for the CN stretch of acetonitrile linked to Brønsted and Lewis sites on ferrierite (2.05 and 3.6 cm μmol−1, respectively) [53]. Also, the center of gravity of both sets of bands have been determined, as a measurement of the average strength of acid sites, taking into account that shifting of the center of gravity to higher wavenumbers indicates stronger acidity. Table 2 shows the calculated density of both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, along with the corresponding center of gravity of both composite bands. The analysis reveals the presence of both Lewis and Bronsted acidic sites in all samples, except for Ni/La-TiO2 catalyst that shows only Bronsted acidic sites. Catalysts supported on La-modified alumina and titania-alumina possess similar content and strength of Lewis and Brønsted sites, and exhibit the strongest Lewis sites among the four catalysts. On the other hand, Ni/La-TiO2 shows a much lower content of Brønsted sites but with higher strength and is virtually free of Lewis sites, whereas Ni/La-Clay exhibits the strongest Brønsted acidity although the density of these sites is half that of Ni/La-Al2O3 and Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3. 3.2 Catalytic performance The evolution of ethanol conversion and hydrogen yield with reaction time over each catalyst are shown in Figs. 3 and 4 , respectively. The four catalysts were quite active with initial conversions between 50 and 100 %. However, conversion decreased with time for three catalysts though with different pace: while Ni/La-Clay lost 64 % of the initial activity between 15 and 250 min on stream, the drop was of 40 % for Ni/La-TiO2 and just 12.5 % for Ni/La-Al2O3 (Fig. 3A). At a variance, conversion over Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3 catalyst increased almost 20 %. The thermogravimetric studies of the used catalysts (see section 3.3 below) showed the presence of different amounts of carbon on their surfaces, higher for the most deactivated catalysts, which could explain the observed deactivation. Nevertheless, in all cases conversion tended to stabilize after 230 min. By contrast, hydrogen yields were more similar and stable with run time, with a strong decay only observed for Ni/La-Al2O3, which also showed the higher initial yield (Fig. 4A). After 130 min, yields were stabilized in the order: Ni/La-Al2O3 > Ni/La-Clay = Ni/La-TiO2 > Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3. To explore the regenerability of the catalysts, after the first run they were reactivated in a flow of 10 % O2 in He and tested catalytically again. This reactivation of the catalysts did not modify the ethanol conversion trends observed, say, Ni/La-Clay and Ni/La-TiO2 deactivated strongly, Ni/La-Al2O3 deactivated more softly, reproducing the previous results, and Ni/La-Al2O3-TiO2 remained stable, though initial ethanol conversion increased twofold for Ni/La-TiO2 and a 50 % for Ni/La-Al2O3-TiO2 (Fig. 3B). A remarkable improvement in hydrogen yield was achieved after catalyst reactivation treatment for catalysts Ni/La-Clay and Ni/La-TiO2 (Fig. 4B), which presented a parallel, fast decaying evolution. Evolution of H2 yield on reactivated Ni/La-Al2O3 and Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3 followed the same trends than on the fresh counterparts but, while on Ni/La-Al2O3 yields were lower after reactivation, they were higher on Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3. Consequently, after 200 min on stream the order of yields was: Ni/La-Clay ≥ Ni/La-TiO2 > Ni/La-Al2O3 ≥ Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3. To understand the different evolution of activity and performance in ESR of the catalysts, it is necessary to analyse the nature and evolution of the chemical species produced by this reaction network. Evolution of the yields of carbon-containing products with run time is reported in Figs. 5–8 . Main products on the less active catalyst, fresh Ni/La-TiO2, were acetaldehyde, methane and CO2 (Fig. 5a), and the observed loss of activity was mainly due to the decrease of methane formation, partially compensated by the increase of CO2 formation. Notably formation of ethylene was very low. Methane can come from thermal decomposition of acetaldehyde (8) or CO2 methanation (11). This evolution indicates that, in this case, it was formed by methanation, which was deactivating with time. The strong increase of initial activity after the catalyst reactivation, and its fast deactivation, (Fig. 5b) was mostly caused by the increase of formation of methane and CO, which ran in parallel, indicating that in this case they probably come from acetaldehyde decomposition (8). As yields of acetaldehyde did not vary, it may mean that new type of active centres were generated by the reactivation treatment. Evolution of the yields on fresh Ni/La-Clay catalyst (Fig. 6a) resembles that on the reactivated Ni/La-TiO2, with high initial yields of methane and CO that decreased fast in parallel, and more stable trends of the other products, but with higher acetaldehyde yield. The evolution of the former, and the soft decrease of acetaldehyde formation, caused the observed fast deactivation (Fig. 3a). Interestingly, formation of ethane was higher (around 5%) and stable. After reactivation, the trends were similar (Fig. 6b) but with higher yields of CO2 and lower yields of acetaldehyde (that increased when those of CO2 decreased), which indicates a higher activity of acetaldehyde steam reforming (6). This may explain the increase of hydrogen yield observed after reactivation (cf. Fig. 4a and b). Products distribution and trends of yield evolution are quite different for the two alumina containing catalysts, but similar between them (Figs. 7 and 8). The main product was ethylene, which yield increased with time. As its formation by ethanol dehydration (4) does not generates hydrogen, this may explain why having much higher activity in the long term (after 120 min on stream) their hydrogen yields did not differ so much from those of Ni/La-Clay and Ni/La-TiO2. The other main products were acetaldehyde, acetone and CO2, in decreasing order. Very little methane and practically no CO were detected. These similarities seem to point to a very similar active species and surface properties of both catalysts. Reactivation of Ni/La-Al2O3 with oxygen treatment recovered the initial activity and its deactivation trend (Fig. 3) but modified product distribution (Fig. 7b) with a higher ethylene formation at the expenses of acetaldehyde and acetone, indicating a slight shift of the primary reactions from dehydrogenation (3) to dehydration (4), and a minor formation of methane. Similar trends were found after reactivation of Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3 (Fig. 8b), but with a higher formation of methane and CO2, which may account for the bigger decrease of acetaldehyde formation, compared to that on reactivated Ni/La-Al2O3. This may also explain the observed increase of hydrogen yield observed with this catalyst upon reactivation (Fig. 4b). 3.3 Characterization of used catalysts To understand the different stability trends observed, the carbon deposited during the catalytic tests was studied gravimetrically by TPO (Fig. 9 ). The first weight loss below 100 °C for both Ni/La-Al2O3 and Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3 (about 5%), was attributed to water removal [54]. The weight loss at higher temperatures, from 415 °C to 650 °C, generally due to the oxidation of coke deposits with different degrees of graphitization [55,56], was 11, 35 and 43 wt.% for Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3, Ni/La-TiO2 and Ni/La-Clay, respectively. As could be expected, the faster the deactivation of the catalyst the higher the amount of carbon detected after reaction, which supports the hypothesis of coke formation as the main cause of deactivation. It is noteworthy that the amount of deposited carbon seems not to be related to the content or strength of Lewis acid centers, nor to the content of Brønsted sites. But, meaningfully, the highest amounts of deposited carbon were found on the two catalysts with the strongest Lewis acidic centres, Ni/La-TiO2 and Ni/La-Clay (Table 2). The pattern of the differential thermogravimetry of Ni/La-Clay (Fig. 9b) showed a single symmetric peak at 590 °C, that of Ni/La-TiO2 one asymmetric peak near 575 °C, broadened to the lower temperatures, and that of Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3 two peaks, one also at 575 °C and a weak one at 425 °C. Comparison of this latter with those of Ni/La-TiO2 and Ni/La-Al2O3 seems to indicate that on this mixed support catalyst coke deposition is related to TiO2 and not to Al2O3. If one considers that the four catalysts were modified with lanthana, and that it is broadly accepted that lanthanum plays a role in preventing carbon formation [19], it can be concluded the lanthana was adequately interacting only with the surface of alumina, and not with those of titania or the modified clay. 3.4 General discussion Usually nickel catalysts are activated by reduction of the metal with hydrogen, but pretreatment with hydrogen at high temperatures can cause sintering and reduced metal dispersion. The use of softer reducers (ethanol combined with water) can avoid these problems. Furthermore, it has been shown that pretreatment with oxygen provides better catalytic activity for CO oxidation compared to treatment with hydrogen [57]. In our work, catalysts were pretreated with oxygen and nickel species were reduced with the ethanol-water mixture during the initial stages of reaction. The lowest ESR activity was shown by fresh Ni/La-TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 4) and may be due to its low surface area, but also to crystalline structure, particle size, and surface hydroxyl groups of TiO2 [20]. The small decrease of initial activity was due to a decrease of methane formation, partly balanced by increase of CO2 formation (Fig. 5A), indicating the decrease of methanation reaction (11). One might initially assume that the further soft decrease of activity was related to the low formation of ethylene; however, this catalyst showed the second higher amount of carbon deposits among the four catalysts (Fig. 9b). This could indicate that the strongest Lewis acid centres inhibit the desorption of ethylene, thus favouring its polymerization to carbon deposits. Reactivation of this catalyst doubled initial conversion, and increased even more initial hydrogen yield, but rapid deactivation followed. The increased conversion is due to the increase of methane and CO formation (Fig. 5B), whose deactivation runs in parallel, and is not accompanied by the decrease of CO2 yield. This implies that both products come from acetaldehyde decomposition (8), indicating that a new type of active centres has been generated by the reactivation process, as the route of formation of methane in ESR depends on the nature of the active centres. Such generation may be caused by the removal of carbonaceous deposits. If their amount is high, the oxidation of carbon by oxygen can create much localized hot spots on the surface of the catalyst, which could lead to the mobility of atoms near the surface, thus generating new active metal centres. The increased joint yield of acetaldehyde, methane and CO upon reactivation means an increased dehydrogenation of ethanol (3), which explains that increase of hydrogen yield observed, and supports that interpretation. Despite having the lowest surface area, Ni/La-Clay showed the highest initial conversion and hydrogen yield, but also the fastest deactivation, for both fresh and reactivated samples (Figs. 3 and 4). Both features are mostly due to the evolution of the formation of methane and CO, which run in parallel, indicating they are formed by acetaldehyde decomposition (8) as on regenerated Ni/La-TiO2. This fast collapse of activity may be understood as due to its textural properties (Fig. 1d) and carbon deposition during reaction, the highest evidenced by TPO (Fig. 9). The pillaring of the montmorillonite present in Clay may allow the maximum dispersion of Ni inside the laminar pores of this support due to its strong metal–support interaction [58], thus giving very high initial activity. However, at the same time, the small size of the pores (less than 3.8 nm) and even smaller pore entries (evidenced by the type of hysteresis of its nitrogen adsorption isotherm) ease the rapid blocking of the accessibility of those Ni centres by carbon deposition. Alike Ni/La-TiO2, Ni/La-Clay produced the highest amount of carbon deposits and low ethylene formation, what can be related to the presence of the strongest Brønsted sites (and in higher amount than in Ni/La-TiO2). Reactivation of used Ni/La-Clay recovered initial conversion and the overall trend of activity evolution (Fig. 3). However, the yields of CO2 almost doubled at expenses of acetaldehyde yield (cf. Fig. 5A and B). This means that the rate of the primary ethanol dehydrogenation (3) was the same but acetaldehyde decomposition (8) is now accompanied by acetaldehyde reforming (5). The contribution of the latter may explain the increase of hydrogen yield observed upon reactivation (Fig.4). The features of the evolution of activity and products distribution of Ni/La-Al2O3 (Fig. 7) and Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3 (Fig. 8) catalysts were similar. Unlike the former two catalysts, ethylene was the main product, its formation increasing with run time, followed by CH3CHO, CH3COCH3 and CO2. Very little methane and CO were formed. Evolution of ethylene yield determines the one of ethanol conversion, as all the other yields remained stable or decreased very smoothly. This explains why while ethanol conversion increased with run time on both catalysts, hydrogen yield slightly decreased with run time (Fig. 4). In this case, acetaldehyde formed by ethanol dehydrogenation (3) undergoes steam reforming (6) and condensation (9) but does not decompose to methane and CO (8). It should be noted that the higher formation of ethylene, the coke precursor, it is not accompanied by deactivation. This latter is due to the very low carbon deposition, as shown by TPO results. As coke is formed by polymerization from ethylene (5), the main difference concerning the dehydration route on these two catalysts and the former two is probably not the amount of ethylene primarily formed, but the competence between its desorption and its polymerization, once formed. Both alumina-containing catalysts exhibit a much higher number of Brønsted sites than the former two, but of weaker strength (Table 2); in the absence of the strongest centres that may retain it, ethylene may desorb before polymerizing. This effect could be favoured by a good dispersion of lanthana, whose slightly basic properties could explain the observed acetone formation. Upon reactivation, catalytic conversion on Ni/La-Al2O3 reproduced that on the fresh sample (Fig. 3) but hydrogen yield slightly decreased (Fig. 4), which may be explained by the formation of methane (Fig. 7). At a variance, reactivated Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3 showed a higher initial ethanol conversion, which remained stable at levels similar to the stabilized ones observed with the fresh sample. Interestingly, upon reactivation the formation of methane and CO increased and evolved in parallel. This effect is similar to the one observed with reactivated Ni/La-TiO2, but much smaller. In fact, the TPO of used Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3 differs of that of used Ni/La-Al2O3 by the weight loss with maximum at the same temperature than the thermogram of Ni/La-TiO2. All these results may be due to the non-interaction between titanium oxide and aluminium oxide, as shown by XRD analysis. The similarity of its performance of the catalyst on this mixed oxide support to the one of Ni/La-Al2O3 indicates that nickel was mostly deposited on the alumina support surface and only a small portion on that of titania support. In general, both catalysts Ni/La-Al2O3 and Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3 have a better stability compared to the other two catalysts; the ranking in order of stability is as follows: Ni/La-Al2O3=Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3>Ni/La-TiO2>Ni/La-Clay. This overall comparison of the results on the four catalysts arises the question of the different effect of support modification with lanthana on the stability of the catalysts, because all of them were modified with the same amount and by the same method. It may indicate that lanthanum was properly dispersed over alumina but not on the surfaces of titania and Clay, probably forming separate crystallites. Indeed, XRD patterns did not show reflections corresponding to La-containing crystalline phases for these catalysts, but the contents of lanthana is around 2.7–3.4 mol%. This very low concentration, or particle sizes below the threshold of the technique (5 nm), could explain said absence. Therefore, strong Lewis acid centres remained on the surface of these catalysts, thus producing the carbon deposits and the ensuing deactivation. 4 Conclusions The catalytic performance of lanthanum-modified supported nickel catalyst for ESR depends strongly on the nature of the support, which affects their activity, products nature and distribution and hydrogen production. The efficiency of the support modification with lanthanum for reducing coke deposition and improving catalyst stability also depends on the nature of the underlying support. Catalyst deactivation is due to carbon deposition that is related to the presence of strong Brønsted acid sites. Lanthanum addition to the support stabilizes the activity of alumina supported nickel catalysts by inhibiting carbon deposition, but has not such beneficial effect on titania- or Clay- supported catalysts, probably due to its deficient dispersion on these supports. The oxidative regeneration of the used catalysts allows recovering the activity of alumina-containing catalysts and increases the activity and notably hydrogen production (ca. 30 % increase) of the catalysts supported on lanthanum-modified titania and Clay. This unexpected improvement, accompanied by the increase of acetaldehyde reforming, indicates the modification of the nickel active centers, most probably caused by the surface overheating locally caused by the combustion of the deposited coke during the reactivation treatment. It is noteworthy that, despite its low catalytic stability and moderate surface area, the catalyst supported on the modified bentonite exhibit the maximal initial activity and the highest hydrogen production after reactivation. These are a promising starting point for the research and improvement of the use of naturally available materials as supports for this type of catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The effect of support nature on the catalytic performance of Ni-based catalysts for ethanol steam reforming (ESR) was investigated. Nickel catalysts supported on lanthanum-modified Al2O3, TiO2, Al2O3-TiO2 and Al-pillared bentonite (denoted as Clay) were prepared by impregnation, characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsoption-desorption, IR spectroscopy of acetonitrile adsorption and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and evaluated at 500 °C under atmospheric pressure. Both Ni/La-Al2O3 and Ni/La-TiO2-Al2O3 exhibited the best stability, whereas Ni/La-TiO2 and Ni/La-Clay deactivated quickly but with similar or higher H2 production. Catalyst deactivation was caused by carbon deposition, which formation was related to strong Brønsted sites. Efficiency of lanthanum as inhibitor of carbon deposition depended on the support nature. Oxidative regeneration allowed recovering initial activity of all used catalysts and even improving the performance of the latter two catalysts. This unexpected improvement can be due to change of nickel centres nature, caused by local overheating during the deposited carbon combustion.
coredata.dc:title: Nickel catalysts promoted with lanthanum for ethanol steam reforming: Influence of support and treatment on activity
